title: 105_hr3573
content: LIMITATION ON DISBURSEMENTS FROM THE EXCHANGE STABILIZATION FUND TO CERTAIN COUNTRIES. Section 5302 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to countries not in compliance with IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot exceed $500,000,000 for international rescue plans unless the country meets IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury must consider all expenditures, loans, obligations, or guarantees made through the stabilization fund for a foreign entity or government that exceeds the limitation imposed. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on U.S. actions to monitor foreign government compliance with commitments to the IMF in financial assistance packages. The Secretary of the Treasury reports to Congress on monitoring foreign government compliance with IMF commitments in financial assistance packages in Asia. The report includes actions taken by the US Executive Director at the IMF and the Department of the Treasury to enforce these commitments. Additionally, there is a focus on monitoring the effects of the Asian financial crisis on the US and other economies. The Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with the United States Trade Representative, monitors Asian countries' progress in implementing commitments under international agreements to provide market access for foreign goods and services. Reports are submitted to Congress every two months until financial assistance is terminated for each country. Progress in resolving trade disputes, particularly with the Republic of Korea, is included in the reports. The report includes progress on market access for foreign automobiles in Korea, implementation of obligations under the US-Korea Memorandum of Understanding, compliance with commitments by Indonesia regarding its "National Car" program, and reforms required by the IMF for corporate governance and structure in Asian countries. The report details measures to prevent financial failure in industries like semiconductor, steel, motor vehicles, and paper. It also describes IMF reform measures for deregulation, privatization, and trade liberalization in Asian countries. The Secretary will take action against countries failing to provide market access for foreign goods and services. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor Asian exports to countries receiving financial assistance and report to Congress every two months. The Secretary, along with the Treasury Secretary and the US Trade Representative, will take action to ensure market access for Asian exports in response to the financial crisis in Asia. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor Asian exports to the US for any significant increase due to currency fluctuations or government subsidies. Reports will be sent to Congress every two months until financial assistance is terminated. Appropriate action will be taken if dumping or subsidization harms US industries. The Secretary of Commerce will consult with import-sensitive US industries to share relevant information for monitoring and reporting requirements. The Secretary, in consultation with the US Trade Representative, will annually report to Congress on the impact of financial assistance on trade relations between Asian countries and others. SEC. 4. FULL ENFORCEMENT OF TRADE LAW REMEDIES. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study with import-sensitive US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. This study will address fluctuations in exchange rates and the treatment of low-interest loans compared to private lenders' rates under US laws. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will determine the appropriate treatment of subsidies received by foreign companies, even if they have been sold, privatized, or declared bankruptcy. A report on the study must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. The provisions of this Act will expire 8 years after its enactment.
